PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE1 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The  proposed  project  will  increase  water  supply  availability  and  efficiency  to  the 
residents of Colombo.  The project will rehabilitate the distribution system, reduce the Non 
Revenue Water (NRW), and enhance the institutional, operational and project management 
capacity of NWSDB. In order to provide the needs of the National Water Supply and Drainage 
Board (NWSDB) and ensure its effectiveness, review of capacity building from previous projects 
and  further  proposals  for  the  institution  and  management  enhancement,  exploring  the 
independent autonomous utility and company or management outsourcing under the NWSDB is 
required. The assessment of current NRW and targeted NRW impacts the tariff schedule, 
analysis of the best practice for the NRW reduction such as zone management in the project 
design are also required.  Project preparatory support to NWSDB will help enhance immediate 
start-up of the project after the approval of the loan. All these warrant the project preparatory 
technical assistance.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

$700,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by the ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will finance the remaining $100,000. The detailed 
cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The  technical  assistance  will  require  19  person-months  of  inputs  from  international 
experts  and  45  person-months  of  inputs  from  national  experts.  One  international  NRW 
consultant firm with one national consultant firm will be engaged. The consultants will provide 
the best practice on NRW management and incorporate the institutional, operational aspects in 
the project design. An individual international consultant will be recruited, mainly to achieve 
project readiness and help to implement the project. The firm under one package will use the 
quality- and cost-based method of selection (QCBS) with a standard quality-cost ratio of 80:20. 
A Simplified Technical Proposal (STP) will be used for the selection of a firm. The summary of 
consulting services requirement is presented in Table A4.3.

5.  The outline terms of references for the project preparatory TA consultants are described 
in paragraphs 6 to 9.  
 
6.  During the first five months of the TA, from December 2011 to April 2012, the design of 
the project will be formulated and mutually agreed upon between the government and ADB. 
Tasks during this period will include (i) detailed review of  previous projects, especially on 
capacity building components, (ii) initial assessment of NRW in the current water supply system, 
(iii)  assessment  of  the  financial  position  and  performance  of  NWSDB,  (iv)  assessment  of 
appropriate institutional arrangements, (v) preparation of appropriate environmental and social 
safeguards documents, (vi) preparation of financial and economic analysis; (vii) assessment of 
governance  risks  in  the  areas  of  financial  management,  procurement,  corruption,  and 
development of risk mitigation measures based on the assessment, (viii) social poverty and 
gender analysis, and preparation of a gender action plan to ensure gender mainstreaming, and 
(ix) proposal of implementation schedule and procurement plan, as well as required consultants’ 
inputs under the project. In order to expedite preparation of the project design, these tasks will 
be led by international consulting firm, with inputs from the national consulting firm.   
 
7.  Under the agreed project framework, over ten months from January to November 2012, 
the consultancy firm will assist NWSDB in developing specific project proposal and feasibility 
study. Specific tasks will include (i) support NWSDB for preparing components of project, (ii) 
detailed assessment of NRW in the current system including water balance establishment, 
service  assessment,  pilot  areas  assessment,  water  loss  calculation,  billing  Geographic 
Information System (GIS) and IT system review, etc, (iii) institutional support for NWSDB in 
terms  of  NRW  reduction,  and  project  management,  and  (iv)  support  to  NWSDB  for 
strengthening their functions in terms of development planning, procurement, and financial 
management. 
 
8.  After the formulation of the project design, some consultants will continue their support 
to the NWSDB for the next five months until November 2012. Specific tasks will include (i) 
support to PMU for developing subproject monitoring and evaluation system, (ii) support for 
NRW institutional and management development of NWSDB, and (iii) support to PMU and 
NWSDB in engaging consultants for the project.

9.  The international water supply NRW expert will take the lead as project team leader to 
work  with  national  water  supply  engineer  as  deputy  team  leader  to  oversee  the  project 
preparation.  International  and  national  water  supply  NRW  experts,  with  background  and 
experience working on NRW issues, will take the lead in NRW assessment and develop the 
NRW management strategy for the project. They will work closely on the design of the project. 
The  international  institutional  expert’s  and  national  institutional  expert  will  undertake  the 
required institutional analysis and propose appropriate institutional arrangements for the project. 
Both international and national public private partnership expert will review the international best 
practice and work with institutional experts to come up with a suitable management model for 
the reduction of NRW. One national water supply engineer will work on the project design. 
Project economic/financial analysts will assess the project from financial and economic aspects. 
The  procurement  specialist  will  help  formulate  a  procurement  plan  for  the  project.  The 
international environmental safeguards specialist and international social safeguards specialist 
will  assess  environmental  and  social  safeguards  issues  and  prepare  required  safeguards 
documents.  The  national  social  development  /  gender  expert  will  review  the  participatory 
process  and  undertake  a  social  and  gender  analysis.  He/she  will  also  prepare  a  social 
assessment  report  and  gender  action  plan.  To  conduct  a  proper  affordability  analysis,  a 
socioeconomic survey will be conducted. The social development/gender specialist will work 
closely with the Project Economic/Financial Analyst to assess affordability, particularly for the 
poor. International and national project management specialists will work on project readiness.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  The Ministry of Water Supply and Drainage (MWSD) will be the executing agency for 
the  technical  assistance.  The  NWSDB  will  be  the  implementing  agency  for  the  technical 
assistance,  and  will  appoint  a  project  director.  The  consultants  will  closely  work  with  the 
implementing  agency.  At  the  central  level,  a  national  steering  committee  (NSC)  will  be 
established, with the secretary of MWSD as the chairperson, and senior officials from the 
Ministry  of  Finance  and  Planning  (both  from  the  Department  of  External  Resources  and 
Department  of  National  Planning),  the  Ministry  of  Economic  Development,  the  Finance 
Commission, Chairman of NWSDB, and the project director. The NSC will meet at least twice 
during the first phase of the technical assistance, and at least one more time before completion, 
to provide policy guidance and ensure necessary linkages and coherence with relevant policies, 
projects and programs of other ministries.  
 
11.  The government and NWSDB will provide (i) all relevant documents, data, statistics, 
information, and maps that are available at its disposal; (ii) appropriate and qualified counterpart 
staff, including their field per diem and field transportation; (iii) technical assistance director from 
the  implementing  agency,  to  be  assigned  before  the  consultants’  mobilization;  (iv)  office 
accommodation and office equipment, including desks and chairs, and local communication; 
(v) logistical assistance for the workshops and seminars, including the venue, and identifying 
and inviting the invitees; and (vi) utility costs, covering electricity and water. Disbursements 
under the TA will be  made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (May 2010, as amended).
